summary: This section of "Atomic Habits" discusses the profound influence of social environment on habit formation, emphasizing how we acquire habits through imitation and conformity. It highlights that people pick up habits from those around them, copying behaviors from family, peers, and coworkers. Closeness increases the likelihood of imitation, with friends and family exerting invisible peer pressure. Joining cultures where desired behaviors are the norm is effective for building better habits. When unsure how to act, people look to the group for guidance, and the normal behavior of the tribe often outweighs individual desires. Fitting in with a tribe makes change attractive, while behaviors earning respect, approval, and status are sought after. Imitating successful individuals is driven by a desire for success. The culture one lives in determines which behaviors are attractive, with a tendency to adopt habits praised and approved by the culture to fit in and belong. People imitate habits of close contacts, the majority, and those with status and prestige.

evidence.verbatim_text: [02:37:15,347,02:37:17,309] We pick up habits from the people around us.
[02:37:17,890,02:37:23,696] We copy the way our parents handle arguments, the way our peers flirt with one another, the way our co-workers get results.
[02:37:49,546,02:37:54,509] As a general rule, the closer we are to someone, the more likely we are to imitate some of their habits.
[02:38:15,333,02:38:19,656] Our friends and family provide a sort of invisible peer pressure that pulls us in their direction.
[02:38:49,233,02:38:52,134] We soak up the qualities and practices of those around us.
[02:38:53,175,02:38:59,937] One of the most effective things you can do to build better habits is join a culture where your desired behavior is the normal behavior.
[02:42:52,195,02:42:55,737] Whenever we are unsure how to act, we look to the group to guide our behavior.
[02:42:56,218,02:42:59,980] We are constantly scanning our environment and wondering, what is everyone else doing?
[02:43:13,609,02:43:18,132] The normal behavior of the tribe often overpowers the desired behavior of the individual.
[02:44:12,003,02:44:15,485] When changing your habits means fitting in with the tribe, change is very attractive.
[02:44:45,358,02:44:49,623] We are drawn to behaviors that earn us respect, approval, admiration, and status.
[02:45:07,239,02:45:11,441] We try to copy the behavior of successful people because we desire success ourselves.
[02:46:33,885,02:46:40,229] We tend to adopt habits that are praised and approved of by our culture because we have a strong desire to fit in and belong to the tribe.
[02:46:41,529,02:46:50,334] We tend to imitate the habits of three social groups, the close, family and friends, the many, the tribe, and the powerful, those with status and prestige.
